title: 7 - Wrapping up
text:
Resources to keep learning


https://www.tidymodels.org/




https://www.tmwr.org/




http://www.feat.engineering/




https://smltar.com/



Follow us on Twitter and at the tidyverse blog for updates!

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Metrics for model performance 




augment(tree_fit, new_data = frog_test) %>%
  metrics(latency, .pred)
#> # A tibble: 3 √ó 3
#>   .metric .estimator .estimate
#>   <chr>   <chr>          <dbl>
#> 1 rmse    standard      59.2  
#> 2 rsq     standard       0.380
#> 3 mae     standard      40.2



RMSE: difference between the predicted and observed values ‚¨áÔ∏è
\(R^2\): squared correlation between the predicted and observed values ‚¨ÜÔ∏è
MAE: similar to RMSE, but mean absolute error ‚¨áÔ∏è

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Metrics for model performance 

augment(tree_fit, new_data = frog_test) %>%
  rmse(latency, .pred)
#> # A tibble: 1 √ó 3
#>   .metric .estimator .estimate
#>   <chr>   <chr>          <dbl>
#> 1 rmse    standard        59.2

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Metrics for model performance 

augment(tree_fit, new_data = frog_test) %>%
  group_by(reflex) %>%
  rmse(latency, .pred)
#> # A tibble: 3 √ó 4
#>   reflex .metric .estimator .estimate
#>   <fct>  <chr>   <chr>          <dbl>
#> 1 low    rmse    standard        94.3
#> 2 mid    rmse    standard       101. 
#> 3 full   rmse    standard        51.2

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Metrics for model performance 

frog_metrics <- metric_set(rmse, msd)
augment(tree_fit, new_data = frog_test) %>%
  frog_metrics(latency, .pred)
#> # A tibble: 2 √ó 3
#>   .metric .estimator .estimate
#>   <chr>   <chr>          <dbl>
#> 1 rmse    standard      59.2  
#> 2 msd     standard      -0.908

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text: Dangers of overfitting ‚ö†Ô∏è

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text: Dangers of overfitting ‚ö†Ô∏è

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Dangers of overfitting ‚ö†Ô∏è 

tree_fit %>%
  augment(frog_train)
#> # A tibble: 456 √ó 6
#>    treatment  reflex    age t_o_d     latency .pred
#>    <chr>      <fct>   <dbl> <fct>       <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1 control    full   467950 morning        33  39.8
#>  2 control    full   464870 morning        19  66.7
#>  3 control    full   464610 morning         2  66.7
#>  4 control    full   469650 morning        39  39.8
#>  5 control    full   467600 morning        42  39.8
#>  6 control    full   410460 afternoon      20  59.8
#>  7 control    full   427685 night          31  83.1
#>  8 control    full   468530 morning        21  39.8
#>  9 gentamicin full   465800 morning        30  64.6
#> 10 control    full   393475 afternoon      43 174. 
#> # ‚Ä¶ with 446 more rows

We call this ‚Äúresubstition‚Äù or ‚Äúrepredicting the training set‚Äù

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Dangers of overfitting ‚ö†Ô∏è 

tree_fit %>%
  augment(frog_train) %>%
  rmse(latency, .pred)
#> # A tibble: 1 √ó 3
#>   .metric .estimator .estimate
#>   <chr>   <chr>          <dbl>
#> 1 rmse    standard        49.4

We call this a ‚Äúresubstition metric‚Äù

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Dangers of overfitting ‚ö†Ô∏è 



tree_fit %>%
  augment(frog_train) %>%
  rmse(latency, .pred)
#> # A tibble: 1 √ó 3
#>   .metric .estimator .estimate
#>   <chr>   <chr>          <dbl>
#> 1 rmse    standard        49.4

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Dangers of overfitting ‚ö†Ô∏è 



tree_fit %>%
  augment(frog_train) %>%
  rmse(latency, .pred)
#> # A tibble: 1 √ó 3
#>   .metric .estimator .estimate
#>   <chr>   <chr>          <dbl>
#> 1 rmse    standard        49.4



tree_fit %>%
  augment(frog_test) %>%
  rmse(latency, .pred)
#> # A tibble: 1 √ó 3
#>   .metric .estimator .estimate
#>   <chr>   <chr>          <dbl>
#> 1 rmse    standard        59.2




‚ö†Ô∏è Remember that we‚Äôre demonstrating overfitting


‚ö†Ô∏è Don‚Äôt use the test set until the end of your modeling analysis

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Your turn

Use augment() and metrics() to compute regression metrics.
Compute the metrics for both training and testing data.
Notice the evidence of overfitting! ‚ö†Ô∏è



05:00

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Dangers of overfitting ‚ö†Ô∏è 



tree_fit %>%
  augment(frog_train) %>%
  metrics(latency, .pred)
#> # A tibble: 3 √ó 3
#>   .metric .estimator .estimate
#>   <chr>   <chr>          <dbl>
#> 1 rmse    standard      49.4  
#> 2 rsq     standard       0.494
#> 3 mae     standard      33.4



tree_fit %>%
  augment(frog_test) %>%
  metrics(latency, .pred)
#> # A tibble: 3 √ó 3
#>   .metric .estimator .estimate
#>   <chr>   <chr>          <dbl>
#> 1 rmse    standard      59.2  
#> 2 rsq     standard       0.380
#> 3 mae     standard      40.2




What if we want to compare more models?


And/or more model configurations?


And we want to understand if these are important differences?

text:
Your turn

If we use 10 folds, what percent of the training data

ends up in analysis
ends up in assessment

for each fold?




03:00

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Resampling 

vfold_cv(frog_train) ## v = 10 is default
#> #  10-fold cross-validation 
#> # A tibble: 10 √ó 2

#>    <list>           <chr> 
#>  1 <split [410/46]> Fold01
#>  2 <split [410/46]> Fold02
#>  3 <split [410/46]> Fold03
#>  4 <split [410/46]> Fold04
#>  5 <split [410/46]> Fold05
#>  6 <split [410/46]> Fold06
#>  7 <split [411/45]> Fold07
#>  8 <split [411/45]> Fold08
#>  9 <split [411/45]> Fold09
#> 10 <split [411/45]> Fold10

text:
Resampling 

vfold_cv(frog_train, v = 5)

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Resampling 
What is in this?

frog_folds <- vfold_cv(frog_train, v = 10)
frog_folds$splits[1:3]
#> [[1]]
#> <Analysis/Assess/Total>
#> <410/46/456>
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> <Analysis/Assess/Total>
#> <410/46/456>
#> 
#> [[3]]
#> <Analysis/Assess/Total>
#> <410/46/456>


Talk about a list column, storing non-atomic types in dataframe

text:
Resampling 

bootstraps(frog_train)
#> # Bootstrap sampling 
#> # A tibble: 25 √ó 2
#>    splits            id         
#>    <list>            <chr>      
#>  1 <split [456/159]> Bootstrap01
#>  2 <split [456/168]> Bootstrap02

#>  4 <split [456/176]> Bootstrap04

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Your turn

Create:

cross-validation folds with stratification
bootstrap folds (change times from the default)
validation resample




05:00

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Resampling 

vfold_cv(frog_train, strata = latency)
#> #  10-fold cross-validation using stratification 
#> # A tibble: 10 √ó 2
#>    splits           id    
#>    <list>           <chr> 
#>  1 <split [408/48]> Fold01
#>  2 <split [408/48]> Fold02
#>  3 <split [408/48]> Fold03
#>  4 <split [409/47]> Fold04
#>  5 <split [411/45]> Fold05
#>  6 <split [412/44]> Fold06
#>  7 <split [412/44]> Fold07
#>  8 <split [412/44]> Fold08
#>  9 <split [412/44]> Fold09
#> 10 <split [412/44]> Fold10


Stratification often helps, with very little downside

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Resampling 

bootstraps(frog_train, times = 10)
#> # Bootstrap sampling 
#> # A tibble: 10 √ó 2
#>    splits            id         
#>    <list>            <chr>      
#>  1 <split [456/162]> Bootstrap01
#>  2 <split [456/165]> Bootstrap02
#>  3 <split [456/159]> Bootstrap03
#>  4 <split [456/169]> Bootstrap04
#>  5 <split [456/168]> Bootstrap05
#>  6 <split [456/171]> Bootstrap06
#>  7 <split [456/175]> Bootstrap07
#>  8 <split [456/168]> Bootstrap08
#>  9 <split [456/166]> Bootstrap09
#> 10 <split [456/156]> Bootstrap10

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Resampling 

validation_split(frog_train, strata = latency)
#> # Validation Set Split (0.75/0.25)  using stratification 
#> # A tibble: 1 √ó 2
#>   splits            id        
#>   <list>            <chr>     
#> 1 <split [340/116]> validation


A validation split is just another type of resample

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Evaluating model performance 

set.seed(123)
frog_folds <- vfold_cv(frog_train, v = 10, strata = latency)
frog_folds
#> #  10-fold cross-validation using stratification 
#> # A tibble: 10 √ó 2
#>    splits           id    
#>    <list>           <chr> 
#>  1 <split [408/48]> Fold01
#>  2 <split [408/48]> Fold02
#>  3 <split [408/48]> Fold03
#>  4 <split [409/47]> Fold04
#>  5 <split [411/45]> Fold05
#>  6 <split [412/44]> Fold06
#>  7 <split [412/44]> Fold07
#>  8 <split [412/44]> Fold08
#>  9 <split [412/44]> Fold09
#> 10 <split [412/44]> Fold10


Set the seed when creating resamples

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Evaluating model performance 

fit_resamples(tree_wflow, frog_folds)
#> # Resampling results
#> # 10-fold cross-validation using stratification 
#> # A tibble: 10 √ó 4
#>    splits           id     .metrics         .notes          
#>    <list>           <chr>  <list>           <list>          
#>  1 <split [408/48]> Fold01 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  2 <split [408/48]> Fold02 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  3 <split [408/48]> Fold03 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  4 <split [409/47]> Fold04 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  5 <split [411/45]> Fold05 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  6 <split [412/44]> Fold06 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  7 <split [412/44]> Fold07 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  8 <split [412/44]> Fold08 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  9 <split [412/44]> Fold09 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#> 10 <split [412/44]> Fold10 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>


Where are the fitted models??!??

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Evaluating model performance 

fit_resamples(tree_wflow, frog_folds)
#> # Resampling results
#> # 10-fold cross-validation using stratification 
#> # A tibble: 10 √ó 4
#>    splits           id     .metrics         .notes          
#>    <list>           <chr>  <list>           <list>          
#>  1 <split [408/48]> Fold01 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  2 <split [408/48]> Fold02 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  3 <split [408/48]> Fold03 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  4 <split [409/47]> Fold04 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  5 <split [411/45]> Fold05 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  6 <split [412/44]> Fold06 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  7 <split [412/44]> Fold07 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  8 <split [412/44]> Fold08 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  9 <split [412/44]> Fold09 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#> 10 <split [412/44]> Fold10 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>

Where are the fitted models??!?? üóëÔ∏è

For more advanced use cases, you can extract and save them: https://www.tmwr.org/resampling.html#extract

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Evaluating model performance 

fit_resamples(tree_wflow, frog_folds) %>%
  collect_metrics()
#> # A tibble: 2 √ó 6
#>   .metric .estimator   mean     n std_err .config             
#>   <chr>   <chr>       <dbl> <int>   <dbl> <chr>               
#> 1 rmse    standard   59.6      10  2.31   Preprocessor1_Model1
#> 2 rsq     standard    0.305    10  0.0342 Preprocessor1_Model1


We can reliably measure performance using only the training data üéâ

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Embarrassingly parallel 

doParallel::registerDoParallel()

# Save the assessment set results
ctrl_frog <- control_resamples(save_pred = TRUE)

set.seed(1)
tree_res <- fit_resamples(tree_wflow, frog_folds, control = ctrl_frog)

tree_res %>% collect_metrics()
#> # A tibble: 2 √ó 6
#>   .metric .estimator   mean     n std_err .config             
#>   <chr>   <chr>       <dbl> <int>   <dbl> <chr>               
#> 1 rmse    standard   59.6      10  2.31   Preprocessor1_Model1
#> 2 rsq     standard    0.305    10  0.0342 Preprocessor1_Model1


Each fit is independent of the others

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Comparing metrics 
How do the metrics from resampling compare to the metrics from training and testing?






tree_res %>%
  collect_metrics() %>% 
  select(.metric, mean, n)
#> # A tibble: 2 √ó 3
#>   .metric   mean     n
#>   <chr>    <dbl> <int>
#> 1 rmse    59.6      10
#> 2 rsq      0.305    10


The RMSE previously was

49.36 for the training set
59.16 for test set




Remember that:
‚ö†Ô∏è the training set gives you overly optimistic metrics
‚ö†Ô∏è the test set is precious

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Evaluating model performance 

ctrl_frog <- control_resamples(save_pred = TRUE)

tree_preds <- 
  tree_res %>%
  collect_predictions()

tree_preds
#> # A tibble: 456 √ó 5
#>    id     .pred  .row latency .config             
#>    <chr>  <dbl> <int>   <dbl> <chr>               
#>  1 Fold01  39.6     1      33 Preprocessor1_Model1
#>  2 Fold01  72.1     3       2 Preprocessor1_Model1
#>  3 Fold01  63.8     9      30 Preprocessor1_Model1
#>  4 Fold01  72.1    13      46 Preprocessor1_Model1
#>  5 Fold01  43.3    28      11 Preprocessor1_Model1
#>  6 Fold01  61.7    35      41 Preprocessor1_Model1
#>  7 Fold01  39.6    51      43 Preprocessor1_Model1
#>  8 Fold01 134.     70      20 Preprocessor1_Model1
#>  9 Fold01  70.6    74      21 Preprocessor1_Model1
#> 10 Fold01  39.6   106      14 Preprocessor1_Model1
#> # ‚Ä¶ with 446 more rows

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
tree_preds %>% 
  ggplot(aes(latency, .pred, color = id)) + 
  geom_abline(lty = 2, col = "gray", size = 1.5) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  coord_obs_pred()

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Random forest üå≥üå≤üå¥üåµüå≥üå≥üå¥üå≤üåµüå¥üå≥üåµ

Ensemble many decision tree models
All the trees vote! üó≥Ô∏è
Bootstrap aggregating + random feature selection



Often works well without tuning hyperparameters (more on this tomorrow!), as long as there are enough trees

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Create a random forest model 

rf_spec <- rand_forest(trees = 1000, mode = "regression")
rf_spec
#> Random Forest Model Specification (regression)
#> 
#> Main Arguments:
#>   trees = 1000
#> 
#> Computational engine: ranger

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Create a random forest model 

rf_wflow <- workflow(latency ~ ., rf_spec)
rf_wflow
#> ‚ïê‚ïê Workflow ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê
#> Preprocessor: Formula
#> Model: rand_forest()
#> 
#> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Preprocessor ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ
#> latency ~ .
#> 
#> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Model ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ
#> Random Forest Model Specification (regression)
#> 
#> Main Arguments:
#>   trees = 1000
#> 
#> Computational engine: ranger

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Your turn

Use fit_resamples() and rf_wflow to:

keep predictions
compute metrics
plot true vs.¬†predicted values




05:00

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Evaluating model performance 

ctrl_frog <- control_resamples(save_pred = TRUE)

# Random forest uses random numbers so set the seed first

set.seed(2)
rf_res <- fit_resamples(rf_wflow, frog_folds, control = ctrl_frog)
collect_metrics(rf_res)
#> # A tibble: 2 √ó 6
#>   .metric .estimator   mean     n std_err .config             
#>   <chr>   <chr>       <dbl> <int>   <dbl> <chr>               
#> 1 rmse    standard   55.9      10  1.71   Preprocessor1_Model1
#> 2 rsq     standard    0.370    10  0.0306 Preprocessor1_Model1

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
collect_predictions(rf_res) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(latency, .pred, color = id)) + 
  geom_abline(lty = 2, col = "gray", size = 1.5) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  coord_obs_pred()

title: 4 - Evaluating models
section: How can we compare multiple model workflows at once?
text: How can we compare multiple model workflows at once?

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Evaluate a workflow set

workflow_set(list(latency ~ .), list(tree_spec, rf_spec))
#> # A workflow set/tibble: 2 √ó 4
#>   wflow_id              info             option    result    
#>   <chr>                 <list>           <list>    <list>    
#> 1 formula_decision_tree <tibble [1 √ó 4]> <opts[0]> <list [0]>
#> 2 formula_rand_forest   <tibble [1 √ó 4]> <opts[0]> <list [0]>

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Evaluate a workflow set

workflow_set(list(latency ~ .), list(tree_spec, rf_spec)) %>%
  workflow_map("fit_resamples", resamples = frog_folds)
#> # A workflow set/tibble: 2 √ó 4
#>   wflow_id              info             option    result   
#>   <chr>                 <list>           <list>    <list>   
#> 1 formula_decision_tree <tibble [1 √ó 4]> <opts[1]> <rsmp[+]>
#> 2 formula_rand_forest   <tibble [1 √ó 4]> <opts[1]> <rsmp[+]>

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Evaluate a workflow set

workflow_set(list(latency ~ .), list(tree_spec, rf_spec)) %>%
  workflow_map("fit_resamples", resamples = frog_folds) %>%
  rank_results()
#> # A tibble: 4 √ó 9
#>   wflow_id         .config .metric   mean std_err     n preprocessor model  rank
#>   <chr>            <chr>   <chr>    <dbl>   <dbl> <int> <chr>        <chr> <int>
#> 1 formula_rand_fo‚Ä¶ Prepro‚Ä¶ rmse    55.8    1.67      10 formula      rand‚Ä¶     1
#> 2 formula_rand_fo‚Ä¶ Prepro‚Ä¶ rsq      0.371  0.0304    10 formula      rand‚Ä¶     1
#> 3 formula_decisio‚Ä¶ Prepro‚Ä¶ rmse    59.6    2.31      10 formula      deci‚Ä¶     2
#> 4 formula_decisio‚Ä¶ Prepro‚Ä¶ rsq      0.305  0.0342    10 formula      deci‚Ä¶     2


Lots more available with workflow sets, like collect_metrics(), autoplot() methods, and more!

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Your turn

When do you think a workflow set would be useful?



03:00

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
The final fit 
Suppose that we are happy with our random forest model.
Let‚Äôs verify our performance using the test set.

We‚Äôve shown you fit() and predict() (+ augment()) but there is a shortcut:

# frog_split has train + test info
final_fit <- last_fit(rf_wflow, frog_split) 

final_fit
#> # Resampling results
#> # Manual resampling 
#> # A tibble: 1 √ó 6
#>   splits            id               .metrics .notes   .predictions .workflow 
#>   <list>            <chr>            <list>   <list>   <list>       <list>    
#> 1 <split [456/116]> train/test split <tibble> <tibble> <tibble>     <workflow>

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
What is in final_fit? 

collect_metrics(final_fit)
#> # A tibble: 2 √ó 4
#>   .metric .estimator .estimate .config             
#>   <chr>   <chr>          <dbl> <chr>               
#> 1 rmse    standard      57.1   Preprocessor1_Model1
#> 2 rsq     standard       0.420 Preprocessor1_Model1


These are metrics computed with the test set

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
What is in final_fit? 

collect_predictions(final_fit)
#> # A tibble: 116 √ó 5
#>    id               .pred  .row latency .config             
#>    <chr>            <dbl> <int>   <dbl> <chr>               
#>  1 train/test split  43.3     1      22 Preprocessor1_Model1
#>  2 train/test split 103.      3     106 Preprocessor1_Model1
#>  3 train/test split  76.6     6      39 Preprocessor1_Model1
#>  4 train/test split  43.0     8      50 Preprocessor1_Model1
#>  5 train/test split  43.0    10      63 Preprocessor1_Model1
#>  6 train/test split  42.8    14      25 Preprocessor1_Model1
#>  7 train/test split  51.1    16      48 Preprocessor1_Model1
#>  8 train/test split 163.     17      91 Preprocessor1_Model1
#>  9 train/test split  50.7    32      11 Preprocessor1_Model1
#> 10 train/test split 171.     33     109 Preprocessor1_Model1
#> # ‚Ä¶ with 106 more rows


These are predictions for the test set

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
collect_predictions(final_fit) %>%
  ggplot(aes(latency, .pred)) + 
  geom_abline(lty = 2, col = "deeppink4", size = 1.5) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  coord_obs_pred()

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
What is in final_fit? 

extract_workflow(final_fit)
#> ‚ïê‚ïê Workflow [trained] ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê
#> Preprocessor: Formula
#> Model: rand_forest()
#> 
#> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Preprocessor ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ
#> latency ~ .
#> 
#> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Model ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ
#> Ranger result
#> 
#> Call:
#>  ranger::ranger(x = maybe_data_frame(x), y = y, num.trees = ~1000,      num.threads = 1, verbose = FALSE, seed = sample.int(10^5,          1))

#> Splitrule:                        variance 
#> OOB prediction error (MSE):       3128.496 
#> R squared (OOB):                  0.3523713


Use this for prediction on new data, like for deploying

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Why choose just one final_fit? 
Model stacks generate predictions that are informed by several models.

title: 4 - Evaluating models

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Building a model stack 

library(stacks)


Define candidate members
Initialize a data stack object
Iteratively add candidate ensemble members to the data stack
Evaluate how to combine their predictions
Fit candidate ensemble members with non-zero stacking coefficients
Predict on new data!

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Building a model stack 

stack_ctrl <- control_resamples(save_pred = TRUE, save_workflow = TRUE)

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Building a model stack 

Define candidate members

Start out with a linear regression:

lr_res <- 
  # define model spec
  linear_reg() %>%
  set_mode("regression") %>%
  # add to workflow
  workflow(preprocessor = latency ~ .) %>%
  # fit to resamples
  fit_resamples(frog_folds, control = stack_ctrl)

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Building a model stack 

lr_res
#> # Resampling results
#> # 10-fold cross-validation using stratification 
#> # A tibble: 10 √ó 5
#>    splits           id     .metrics         .notes           .predictions     
#>    <list>           <chr>  <list>           <list>           <list>           
#>  1 <split [408/48]> Fold01 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]> <tibble [48 √ó 4]>
#>  2 <split [408/48]> Fold02 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]> <tibble [48 √ó 4]>
#>  3 <split [408/48]> Fold03 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]> <tibble [48 √ó 4]>
#>  4 <split [409/47]> Fold04 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]> <tibble [47 √ó 4]>
#>  5 <split [411/45]> Fold05 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]> <tibble [45 √ó 4]>
#>  6 <split [412/44]> Fold06 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]> <tibble [44 √ó 4]>
#>  7 <split [412/44]> Fold07 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]> <tibble [44 √ó 4]>
#>  8 <split [412/44]> Fold08 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]> <tibble [44 √ó 4]>
#>  9 <split [412/44]> Fold09 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]> <tibble [44 √ó 4]>
#> 10 <split [412/44]> Fold10 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]> <tibble [44 √ó 4]>

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Building a model stack 
Then, a random forest:

rf_res <- 
  # define model spec
  rand_forest() %>%
  set_mode("regression") %>%
  # add to workflow
  workflow(preprocessor = latency ~ .) %>%
  # fit to resamples
  fit_resamples(frog_folds, control = stack_ctrl)

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Building a model stack 

rf_res
#> # Resampling results
#> # 10-fold cross-validation using stratification 
#> # A tibble: 10 √ó 5
#>    splits           id     .metrics         .notes           .predictions     
#>    <list>           <chr>  <list>           <list>           <list>           
#>  1 <split [408/48]> Fold01 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]> <tibble [48 √ó 4]>
#>  2 <split [408/48]> Fold02 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]> <tibble [48 √ó 4]>
#>  3 <split [408/48]> Fold03 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]> <tibble [48 √ó 4]>
#>  4 <split [409/47]> Fold04 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]> <tibble [47 √ó 4]>
#>  5 <split [411/45]> Fold05 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]> <tibble [45 √ó 4]>
#>  6 <split [412/44]> Fold06 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]> <tibble [44 √ó 4]>
#>  7 <split [412/44]> Fold07 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]> <tibble [44 √ó 4]>
#>  8 <split [412/44]> Fold08 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]> <tibble [44 √ó 4]>
#>  9 <split [412/44]> Fold09 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]> <tibble [44 √ó 4]>
#> 10 <split [412/44]> Fold10 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]> <tibble [44 √ó 4]>

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Building a model stack 

Initialize a data stack object



st <- stacks()

st
#> # A data stack with 0 model definitions and 0 candidate members.

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Building a model stack 

Iteratively add candidate ensemble members to the data stack


st <- st %>%
  add_candidates(lr_res) %>%
  add_candidates(rf_res)

st
#> # A data stack with 2 model definitions and 2 candidate members:
#> #   lr_res: 1 model configuration
#> #   rf_res: 1 model configuration
#> # Outcome: latency (numeric)

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Building a model stack 

Evaluate how to combine their predictions


st <- st %>%
  blend_predictions()

st
#> # A tibble: 2 √ó 3
#>   member     type        weight
#>   <chr>      <chr>        <dbl>
#> 1 rf_res_1_1 rand_forest  0.670
#> 2 lr_res_1_1 linear_reg   0.318

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Building a model stack 

Fit candidate ensemble members with non-zero stacking coefficients


st <- st %>%
  fit_members()

st
#> # A tibble: 2 √ó 3
#>   member     type        weight
#>   <chr>      <chr>        <dbl>
#> 1 rf_res_1_1 rand_forest  0.670
#> 2 lr_res_1_1 linear_reg   0.318

title: 4 - Evaluating models
text:
Building a model stack 

Predict on new data!



frog_test %>%
  select(latency) %>%
  bind_cols(predict(st, frog_test)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(latency, .pred)) + 
  geom_abline(lty = 2, 
              col = "deeppink4", 
              size = 1.5) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  coord_obs_pred()
